title: Transcript: Q&A With the Richmond Fed's Thomas Barkin
summary: Resume Subscription. Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Thomas Barkin was interviewed by Michael S. Derby of The Wall Street Journal on Tuesday. Mr. Barkin discussed what he thinks needs to happen to get the economy back on track, how he expects it to perform, the importance of health policy clarity and his views on what else the Federal Reserve could do to support the economy if needed. The following conversation has been lightly edited for clarity.

title: Stimulus Cops on Lookout for Fake Employees, Identity Theft
summary: Federal government steps up oversight of roughly $3 trillion in spending for businesses and households. WASHINGTON-Congress has thrown nearly $3 trillion at stemming the economic damage caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Now, Washington wants to make sure it knows where it is going.

title: The Flynn Unmaskers Unmasked
summary: Now we know who knew about the Russian calls, including Joe Biden.. When news stories appeared in early 2017 about Michael Flynn's conversation with Russia's ambassador to the U.S., these columns wondered how Mr. Flynn's call was so widely known. The names of private U.S. citizens caught on tape by U.S. intelligence are supposed to be "masked" so their privacy is protected.

title: Judge Sullivan's Bad Judgment
summary: Can Flynn be sentenced when prosecutors say there was no crime?. If the prosecution and defense both want to drop a case, can a federal judge refuse and sentence the defendant anyway? The easy call should be no, which makes all the more bizarre federal Judge Emmet Sullivan's decision Tuesday to invite outside briefs in the Michael Flynn case.

title: The Supreme Court and the Lawyers' Guilds
summary: The Justices may take up a challenge to forced bar association fees.. One reason for the dominance of the progressive legal establishment is that hundreds of thousands of lawyers across the country are forced to join state bar associations that spend their money on political causes against their will. At Friday's private conference, the Supreme Court is expected to consider whether to take a challenge to this practice on First Amendment grounds.

title: Abbott's Coronavirus Test Falls Short of Rival Device
summary: Study indicates Abbott ID Now failed to detect 48% of the positive cases found by another machine. Researchers reported a device manufactured by Abbott Laboratories widely used to swiftly detect coronavirus, including among senior White House officials, missed nearly half of the positive cases detected by another common test.

title: Coronavirus Demands a Privacy Law
summary: Silicon Valley's role in contact tracing and social-distancing enforcement has Americans worried.. Reopening the economy and returning to "normal life" in the absence of a Covid-19 vaccine may be possible, we are told, with a combination of widespread testing and contact tracing. But these solutions will depend heavily on technology, and Silicon Valley doesn't have the best record when it comes to protecting consumer privacy. Congress must step into the breach with federal privacy legislation establishing guardrails for tech companies' handling of our most personal information.

title: Obama's Crocodile Tears for the Rule of Law
summary: The former president has sharp words for Trump but, as usual, little self-awareness.. His foray into the 2020 election this past Friday was pure Barack Obama-pointedly partisan, sometimes entertaining and displaying an amazing lack of self-awareness. In what was likely a preplanned maneuver, a friendly reporter received a recording of the former president's 30-minute pep talk to his administration's alumni association and posted the juicier nuggets online.

title: We're Ready to 'Snap Back' Sanctions
summary: If the U.N. doesn't renew the arms embargo against Iran, the U.S. will use its authority to do so.. The 13-year-old arms embargo on the Iranian regime will expire in October. The embargo was created by the United Nations Security Council but is scheduled to end because of the 2015 Iran nuclear deal, leaving the world's foremost state sponsor of terrorism and anti-Semitism free to import and export combat aircraft, warships, submarines and guided missiles. To prevent this, the Security Council must pass a resolution to extend the arms embargo. If this effort is defeated by a veto, the Trump administration is prepared to exercise all legally available options to extend the embargo.

title: A Covid Drug to Help Fight the Storm
summary: One treatment for my well-known disease could also be used to suppress a deadly reaction in coronavirus patients.. I have a secret I've managed to keep for decades from colleagues at work and neighbors on my block-all but my closest friends.

title: Reasons for Fans to Like a Sports-Free Year
summary: Pass the time with books, family and friends. Then enjoy the restart next year.. In this country, sports come at you hard. They never lag, even when the season ends. Sports Twitter brings ceaseless draft talk, free-agency speculation and beefs between rival players. Seasons extend and extend again. There's always more.

title: 'Natural' Review: Pork Loin vs. Impossible Burger
summary: People use and abuse the idea of the natural: sometimes sensibly, more often sloppily or cynically, to feel better about themselves.. To many of us, a "natural life" is something we can just make out in the rear-view mirror-and ought to go back and embrace. But it's a fool's errand. We've already come too far, and our journey is only beginning. In the years ahead, technology and desire will drive us to remake ourselves and our planet in ways we can hardly imagine.

title: The Michael Flynn Debauchery
summary: The people who administer the American system lost trust in that system and debased our institutions.. Barack Obama is turning into the reverse Oracle of Delphi. He sometimes gets it right for the wrong reasons.

title: Brink's Adds Masks and Gloves to Protection Plans
summary: CFO of cash management company says he paid a premium to secure PPE for global workforce amid the coronavirus pandemic. Firearms, bulletproof vests and armored trucks are typical purchases for Ron Domanico. Yet in recent weeks, the finance chief of The Brink's Co. has dispatched a team to find face masks and other personal protective equipment for his 64,600 employees around the world because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Cisco's Dim View Has a Bright Side
summary: Tech giant still willing to give a forecast even as its business has been hit hard by the pandemic. As Cisco Systems showed Wednesday, bad news is all relative these days.

title: New York City to Limit Fees From Meal-Delivery Apps
summary: Measures aim to bolster restaurants struggling during the pandemic. New bills passed Wednesday in the New York City Council will cap delivery fees charged by services like Grubhub and prohibit other charges, a move lawmakers say will help struggling businesses as the city fights the coronavirus.

title: Tyson Drops Some Beef Prices as Coronavirus Lifts Grocery-Store Costs
summary: Move will help keep beef affordable as meatpacking plants resume operations, company CEO says. Tyson Foods Inc. is lowering some prices it charges supermarkets and restaurants for beef, after coronavirus-driven disruptions at meatpacking plants have led to a surge in meat costs.

title: Amtrak's Acela to Make Comeback, Riders or Not
summary: Railroad's express service between Washington and Boston will restart June 1. WASHINGTON-Amtrak plans to restart its Acela express service between Washington and Boston on June 1, a first step in the national railroad's return from a near-shutdown after the coronavirus crushed rider demand nationwide.

title: Coronavirus Testing Needs to Grow Sharply in U.S., House Panel Is Told
summary: Harvard doctor Ashish Jha calls for a tripling of nation's efforts as it fights coronavirus. WASHINGTON-Prominent public-health doctors told members of a House subcommittee that the country needs to expand its coronavirus testing-by perhaps as much as three times-if the U.S. is to succeed at safely reopening the economy.

title: U.S. Removes Sanctions on Nynas After Restructuring
summary: Venezuela's state-owned oil giant, Petróleos de Venezuela, which is blacklisted by the U.S., reduced its stake in the Swedish oil refiner. The U.S. lifted sanctions on Nynas AB after a restructuring that leaves blacklisted oil giant Petróleos de Venezuela SA with a smaller stake in the Swedish oil refiner, the U.S. Treasury Department said Tuesday.

title: Republican Wins Special House Election in California
summary: Mike Garcia regains seat briefly held by Democrats; candidates face rematch in November for full two-year term. Republican former Navy fighter pilot Mike Garcia won a closely watched special election in California conducted mostly by mail due to the coronavirus pandemic, pulling back into the GOP column a House seat that had been briefly held by a Democrat.

title: Stocks Fall as Powell Says Outlook 'Highly Uncertain'
summary: Shares of beaten-down energy, airline and bank stocks were among the biggest decliners. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 500 points Wednesday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said further stimulus could be needed to support the economy's recovery from the coronavirus-induced contraction.

title: Powell Says Washington Will Need to Spend More to Battle Downturn
summary: 'Reversal of economic fortune has caused a level of pain that is hard to capture in words,' says Fed leader. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell urged the White House and Congress to spend more money to ensure their initial response to the coronavirus-induced economic downturn isn't squandered.

title: Cisco Projects Annual Sales Decline
summary: Network-equipment giant also expects a third straight quarter of lower sales. Network-equipment giant Cisco Systems Inc. posted lower quarterly sales and projected its first annual sales decline in three years, citing economic uncertainty amid the coronavirus pandemic that has taken a toll on its core business of switches and routers.

title: A Dog's Nose Can Do More Than Sniff
summary: New research shows that its cool black skin is perfectly designed to detect subtle differences in temperatures.. How does the world appear to a dog? We all know that they have an astonishing sense of smell, excellent hearing and sharp eyes-enough to build up an extremely detailed map of their surroundings. But recent research suggests that dogs live in an even richer sensory world than we expected. They can directly detect the warmth of a body from several feet away, and they do it with their nose.

title: Corporate America Isn't Betting On a V-Shaped Recovery
summary: Many investors say the market's trajectory suggests a quick comeback, but executives have doubts. Since the coronavirus pandemic began pulling the U.S. economy into a contraction, economists have tried to answer one big question: What kind of shape will the recovery take?

title: Patent Office Throws the Book at Travel Company
summary: Win for Booking Holdings in the Supreme Court could be a win for Big Tech. A trademark case argued in the Supreme Court last week could travel.

title: The Nostalgia We All Need Right Now: A Book About Sesame Street
summary: David Kamp describes the idealists who made 'Sesame Street' and other creative kids programming in the early 1970s, including 'The Electric Company,' 'Free to Be...You and Me,' 'Zoom' and 'Schoolhouse Rock!'. A recent revival of interest in Mister Rogers has offered fans a chance to revisit childhood nostalgia. "Sunny Days: The Children's Television Revolution That Changed America" takes it from there. The new book by David Kamp focuses on the idealists who made "Sesame Street" and other creative programming for young minds in the early 1970s, including "The Electric Company," "Free to Be...You and Me," "Zoom" and "Schoolhouse Rock!" The book traces the road from "Howdy Doody" through "Captain Kangaroo" to the "Sesame Street" neighborhood, a city block with its diverse (human and Muppet) cast, lessons on alphabets and ethics, and snappy songs.

title: Uber Discusses Grubhub Takeover Valuing Food Deliverer at Roughly $6 Billion
summary: Big cost savings that would help pay for the possible deal. Uber Technologies Inc. and Grubhub Inc. are discussing a takeover valuing Grubhub at roughly $6 billion, with big cost savings that would help pay for the deal, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Bankrupt Burger Chain Krystal Strikes Takeover Deal With Senior Lender
summary: The quick-service restaurant chain is selling itself out of bankruptcy to an affiliate of Fortress Investment Group. Krystal Co., the Southern burger chain founded nearly 90 years ago, is selling itself out of bankruptcy to an affiliate of its senior lender Fortress Investment Group LLC.

title: As Coronavirus Cases Fall, Countries Struggle to Measure When It's Safe to Reopen
summary: A popular gauge is becoming more volatile as numbers drop. As the pace of new coronavirus infections slows across Europe, governments are reconsidering how best to measure the progress of the disease and guide their decisions on loosening lockdowns.

title: WSJ Survey: Coronavirus to Cause 17% Unemployment in June
summary: Economists see U.S. growth rebound in second half of year, though GDP is expected to shrink 6.6% in 2020. U.S. unemployment is expected to hit 17% in June as the economy contracts due to efforts to contain the coronavirus pandemic, economists predicted, and the economy is expected to start rebounding in the second half of the year.

title: France Threatens Big Fines for Social Media With Hate-Speech Law
summary: Social-media companies must remove content deemed hateful in France within 24 hours, or face fines of up to 4% of global revenue. PARIS-France is empowering regulators to slap large fines on social-media companies that fail to remove postings deemed hateful, one of the most aggressive measures yet in a broad wave of rules aimed at forcing tech companies to more tightly police their services.

title: Norwegian Fund Excludes Large Canadian Oil Producers
summary: Sovereign-wealth fund cites high carbon emissions from companies' operations. TORONTO-Norway's sovereign-wealth fund said Wednesday that it is blacklisting four of Canada's largest oil producers from its trillion-dollar portfolio, citing high carbon emissions from their operations.

title: Fed Sends Fresh Rebuke to Deutsche Bank
summary: German lender's money-laundering controls again draw attention from U.S. regulator. The Federal Reserve has issued a fresh rebuke over Deutsche Bank AG's money-laundering controls, according to a person familiar with the situation.

title: Federal Reserve Revision Could Help Clear CLO Logjam
summary: Exchange-traded-fund buying buoys investment-grade bonds. Changes by the Federal Reserve to its relief program for asset-backed debt markets could unclog a logjam in Wall Street's pipeline of collateralized loan obligations, or CLOs.

title: Regulators Deny Approval of Chinese Masks in Giant California Order
summary: BYD has $1 billion contract to supply N95 masks for the state. U.S. authorities this month denied initial regulatory approval for N95 masks from BYD Co. , a Chinese company that had secured huge orders for the protective gear including a $1 billion deal with the state of California.

title: Supreme Court Weighs Whether Electoral College Members Must Stick to State's Popular Vote
summary: Cases follow increase in 'faithless' electors in 2016 presidential election and present dueling views of what Constitution's framers had in mind. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court set out to clarify the nation's age-old rules for the Electoral College system of selecting U.S. presidents, considering whether presidential electors can go rogue and ignore the voter-chosen candidate.

title: New York and New Jersey Start to Reopen Their Economies
summary: States allow limited activity in construction, manufacturing and retail amid coronavirus pandemic. Construction firms can resume nonessential operations in the coming days across New Jersey and in the northernmost counties of New York, officials said Wednesday, as both states moved forward with a limited economic restart amid the coronavirus crisis.

title: Investment Giants Want Exchanges to Enforce Labeling System for ETFs
summary: BlackRock, State Street and Invesco among those seeking strict definition of what can be called an exchange-traded fund. BlackRock Inc., State Street Global Advisors and some other large money managers are asking exchanges to enforce a more narrow definition of exchange-traded funds.

title: U.S. Says It Will Trust Small Business Owners When They Say They Need Loans
summary: Move seeks to ease concerns that PPP money won't be forgiven. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration says it will presume borrowers have met the certification requirements for forgivable small-business loans under $2 million in the Paycheck Protection Program, in a move aimed at easing borrower fears that their loans won't be forgiven.

title: 'Reunions,' 'Never Will,' 'Southside' and 'Great American Saturday Night' Reviews: Country Not to Be Missed
summary: With all that's going on in the world, it might be easy to overlook new releases, but fans of roots music-and of other genres, too-should be sure to seek out recent records by Jason Isbell and the 400 Unit, Ashley McBryde, Sam Hunt and Bobby Bare..

title: 'Set My Heart on Fire Immediately' by Perfume Genius Review: Finding Pleasure in a Painful Past
summary: The new album from the indie rocker is a stunning feat, pairing his leanest and most efficient words with some of his most beautiful music..

title: CIOs Spearhead Well-Being Initiatives to Make Remote Work Less Remote
summary: After deploying the tools to support remote work, IT leaders now see their job as helping manage its impact on a now distant workforce. Chief information officers are stepping beyond their traditional roles to help spearhead employee-focused mental health and well-being initiatives during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Working From Home Is Taking a Toll on Our Backs and Necks
summary: Weeks of poor ergonomics on the bed or sofa have led to backaches, neck pain and headaches. For Anthony Flint, one of the most comfortable spots in his house became one of the most dangerous.

title: Manafort Released From Prison to Home Confinement
summary: Manafort will continue serving sentence for tax, bank fraud at home due to coronavirus concerns. President Trump's former campaign chairman Paul Manafort has been released from a federal prison due to coronavirus concerns and will continue serving his 7½ year sentence for tax and bank fraud from his Northern Virginia home, his attorney said Wednesday.

title: What to Watch: Elle Fanning Puts a Faux Spin on a Real Empress in Hulu's 'The Great'
summary: Plus, 'Scoob!' skips the theaters, a series for 'weird girls' and other picks to add to your queue. This week, "American Idol" is getting ready for its big finale-and we have a behind the scenes look at how producers on the singing competition are assembling the big night remotely. Meanwhile, "Workin' Moms" is back on Netflix . Read our profile of creator Catherine Reitman who reflects on what it means to be a working mom just as the world of work-life balance gets turned upside down. And don't forget we are recapping the fifth season of "Billions."

title: Coronavirus Projected to Keep Weighing on Oil Demand
summary: OPEC says the world's demand for crude is on track to fall 18% in the second quarter. Global oil demand this quarter is expected to drop 18% from a year earlier as coronavirus lockdowns continue to sap demand for transportation fuel, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: Pompeo, in Israel, Discusses Annexation Amid Coronavirus Lockdown
summary: Israel's new unity government could begin the annexation process in July. TEL AVIV-Secretary of State Mike Pompeo made a rare diplomatic foray to Israel amid the coronavirus pandemic to advance the Trump administration's Israeli-Palestinian peace plan that allows Israel to annex swaths of the West Bank, a key plank that if implemented could stir tensions within Israel and among key partners.

title: Soaring Prices, Rotting Crops: Coronavirus Triggers Global Food Crisis
summary: Resume Subscription. The coronavirus pandemic hit the world at a time of plentiful harvests and ample food reserves. Yet a cascade of protectionist restrictions, transport disruptions and processing breakdowns has dislocated the global food supply and put the planet's most vulnerable regions in particular peril.

title: 'The Great' Review: Rowdy Romanovs
summary: Comedy meets history in Hulu's series about the exploits of Catherine the Great.. 'You're not great, are you?" Catherine (Elle Fanning) asks her new husband, Peter (Nicholas Hoult), during sex. The czar looks wounded. "Peter the Great, I mean," she adds, at which point he looks relieved. Which he ought not be: Catherine was probably born great. She will certainly achieve greatness. She will not, it is clear, be having nongreatness thrust upon her.

title: The No-Bake Dessert That Doubles As a Cocktail
summary: Boozy, chocolaty, easy to whip up, bourbon balls are a Kentucky classic. They've never tasted better.. THE KENTUCKY DERBY may be delayed until September, but the demand for bourbon, chocolate and quick, easy, no-bake desserts using pantry staples has probably never been higher. Bourbon balls have it all: the booze, the chocolate, the ease, plus the crunch of a sanding-sugar exterior and a luscious center. They are also adaptable, so keep reading even if you currently lack some of the ingredients listed in the recipe at right. The point here is to have fun.

title: Behind Elon Musk's Fight to Reopen Tesla in California: Keep Up With Detroit
summary: With Michigan auto companies coming back next week, the electric-vehicle maker faced a home-state disadvantage. Elon Musk has long cast Tesla Inc. as a tech company, but the coronavirus pandemic-and his battle to resume production-show that the Silicon Valley car maker still has at least as much in common with Detroit as it does with the tech giants down the road.

title: Magazine Publisher Condé Nast to Lay Off About 100 Employees in U.S.
summary: Similar number to be temporarily furloughed as advertising slowdown takes a bite. Condé Nast, publisher of such magazines as the New Yorker, Wired and Vanity Fair, is laying off just under 100 staffers in the U.S., reflecting the continued impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Essential Historical Fiction for Europhiles
summary: From spy novels to Stendhal, the novels that best conjure up vanished worlds, according to three notables. "'Cloud Atlas' by David Mitchell took the concept of historical fiction and transcended it. I sound star-struck, but it is incredibly rewarding to read! 'The Red and The Black' is a classic [of the genre]. Stendhal takes a vain young man from humble beginnings and creates the kind of anti-hero that is popular on TV today. The book is a big bite, but for me, it's the antidote to Victor Hugo's Paris, which is so self-important. Stendhal was interested in puncturing pretension; he was a cynic, and I'm a cynic, so we get along."

title: Yellowstone, Grand Teton Parks to Begin Reopening Monday
summary: Interior secretary says decisions on parks would heavily defer to guidance from local, state and federal health officials. WASHINGTON-Yellowstone and Grand Teton national parks will partly reopen to the public next week, Interior Secretary David Bernhardt said Wednesday, part of a federal push to end several of the closings caused by the coronavirus.

title: The Limits of Anthony Fauci's Expertise
summary: The government disease doctor acknowledges he isn't studying shutdown trade-offs.. Dr. Anthony Fauci has proven he doesn't understand economics. His Tuesday Senate testimony also suggested the limits of his knowledge about public health.

title: The Dr. Fauci of Eastern Ukraine Tackles Coronavirus After Years of War
summary: Serhiy Ryzhenko pivots from bullet wounds and lost limbs to fighting the pandemic amid a continuing conflict. Many compare the struggle with coronavirus to war. In eastern Ukraine, covertly invaded by Russia in 2014, Covid-19 has infected a part of the world already hardened by years of warring with an unwelcome intruder.

title: U.K. Court Quashes 1970s Convictions of Gerry Adams
summary: Panel says former Sinn Féin leader was imprisoned unlawfully. LONDON-The U.K.'s highest court ruled former Sinn Féin President Gerry Adams was imprisoned unlawfully in Northern Ireland during the 1970s and overturned his two convictions for trying to escape jail.

title: Judge Tosses Nassar-Related Charges Against Former College President
summary: Ex-Michigan State head Lou Anna Simon was accused of lying to officers in Larry Nassar investigation. A Michigan judge dismissed all charges against former Michigan State University President Lou Anna Simon Wednesday, ruling there wasn't sufficient evidence to back up allegations she intentionally lied to investigators about the Larry Nassar sexual-abuse scandal.

title: Joe Biden, Title IX and Rights of the Accused
summary: As a former member of the board of trustees of a small college we spent many hours dealing with Title IX when it was first inflicted upon us. The most obvious problem was that the it is in direct conflict with the Fifth and Sixth Amendments to the Constitution.s. Regarding your editorial "Joe Biden Should Love Betsy DeVos" (May 7): Does anyone read the U.S. Constitution anymore, specifically Amendments V and VI, which are prescient in these matters? As a former member of the board of trustees of a small college I spent many hours dealing with Title IX when it was first inflicted on us. The most obvious problem was that it is in direct conflict with these two amendments to the Constitution.

title: Trump, Biden, Tweets and Electoral Purpose
summary: Having a bigger megaphone doesn't overcome a dysfunctional message or imperiled sender, it only serves to amplify them.. Karl Rove's argument that President Trump's dominant social-media reach and interaction over Joe Biden's is an inherent plus for the president ignores that many of the president's Twitter followers and interactions are born from detractors, nonsupporters and opponents ("Joe Biden's Challenge," op-ed, May 7). The president's own words, rantings, contradictions and midnight Tweetstorms are frequently cudgels used to highlight his unfitness to serve. Having a bigger megaphone doesn't overcome a dysfunctional message or imperiled sender; it serves to amplify them.

title: Dakota Bean Farmer Has Roots in Concord Conflict
summary: "Young man," he said, "what we meant in going for those redcoats was this: We always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn't mean we should.". Regarding Terry Wanzek's "The Bean Farmer's Guide to Social Distancing and Personal Freedom" (Cross Country, May 9): Amen. Great piece. It reminds me of something I read in Wilfred McClay's recent book "Land of Hope" in which he quotes a soldier who fought at the battle of Concord in 1775. An interviewer asked him many decades after the battle why he fought. His single reason was priceless. "Young man, what we meant in going for those red-coats was this: we always had governed ourselves, and we always meant to. They didn't mean we should."

title: VE-Day Photo Shows Lack of Concern by White House
summary: In the photo, no one-seven veterans, the youngest 96 years old, and the president, his wife and a current member of the military-was wearing a mask.. Your May 9 front-page photo of President Trump with World War II veterans highlights why so many people around the U.S. are testing positive for Covid-19 or dying of the illness. We're not taking the pandemic seriously enough.

title: J. Edgar Hoover's Ghost Still Haunts Today's FBI
summary: How many of the behaviors and abuses that liberals abhorred in J. Edgar Hoover's FBI have been practiced by James Comey's FBI and Robert Mueller's investigators?. In "What The FBI Coverup Is Covering Up" (Business World, May 9) Holman Jenkins captures in a nutshell where the liberal/progressive movement has wandered in the last 50 years. How many of the behaviors and abuses that liberals abhorred in J. Edgar Hoover's FBI have been practiced by James Comey's FBI and Robert Mueller's investigators? Today's progressives, abetted by their media allies, not only give these abuses a pass but enthusiastically support them. It makes one wonder if many progressives aren't motivated by the noble principles they profess but by a take-no-prisoners ideology where rights and reputations can be trampled in pursuit of the greater cause.

title: Tencent Profit Rises as Coronavirus Fuels Online Games Demand
summary: Tech giant benefits from lockdowns, as Chinese consumers flock to mobile games, online entertainment. Tencent Holdings Ltd. 's first-quarter profit was fueled by strong demand for mobile games as homebound Chinese consumers turned to online entertainment during the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Atul Gawande Steps Down as Haven's CEO
summary: Dr. Gawande will serve as chairman of the health-care venture backed by Amazon, Berkshire and JPMorgan Chase. Atul Gawande is stepping down as the chief executive of Haven, the health-care venture backed by Amazon . com Inc., Berkshire Hathaway Inc. and JPMorgan Chase .

title: Star-Studded Coronavirus Panel Canceled After Flak Over Huawei Sponsorship
summary: National Association of Black Journalists cancels webinar on impact on minorities of false misinformation about pandemic. An effort by Huawei Technologies Co. to dip its toe into the stormy waters of a U.S. political debate backfired after organizers canceled a star-studded online panel sponsored by the Chinese company to discuss the coronavirus and its impact on minority communities.

title: Maersk Expects Container Shipping Volumes to Fall Up to 25%
summary: The boxship operator beat expectations and posted a quarterly profit built partly on cost cuts, higher freight rates. A.P. Moeller-Maersk A/S expects container volumes to fall up to 25% this quarter and plans to cancel dozens of sailings as the Danish shipping giant copes with sliding demand in consumer and industrial markets from the coronavirus pandemic lockdowns.

title: Republicans Float Ideas on Jobless Benefits, State Aid for Coronavirus Response
summary: Senate GOP looks to present alternatives to House Democrats' $3 trillion package. WASHINGTON-Senate Republicans are beginning to formulate their own set of policy ideas for the next bill grappling with the coronavirus pandemic, looking to present alternatives to the House Democrats' package that focuses on trillions of dollars in new aid to states, cities and households.

title: Coronavirus Propels Nextdoor.com Beyond Lost Pets, Peeved Neighbors
summary: CEO Sarah Friar talks about wooing seniors to the platform: 'What will we regret in 12 to 18 months?'. Neighborhood social network Nextdoor Inc. has found a new kind of relevance in the coronavirus era.

title: Germany Needs to Become a Great Power Again
summary: Seventy-five years after V-E Day, only Berlin can confront Europe's cultural and monetary crises.. Thirty years after unification, history is knocking at Germany's door. To answer the call, Germany will have to break some of its deepest taboos, and begin to think and act like a great power again.

title: Judges Are Umpires, Not Ringmasters
summary: Sullivan invites outsiders to weigh in on the Flynn case-an unconstitutional judicial power grab.. The Constitution limits the jurisdiction of federal judges to actual cases and controversies. They may not offer advisory opinions or intrude on executive or legislative powers, except when the other branches have exercised them in an unconstitutional manner. Federal judges are umpires deciding matters about which litigants disagree. If the litigants come to an agreement, there is no controversy. The case is over.

title: Fritz Gerber, Former CEO of Swiss Drug Maker Roche, Dies at 91
summary: Brought in as Valium era waned, he made the company a global leader in biotech and diagnostics. Fritz Gerber seemed like an odd choice when F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Co., a pharmaceutical company now known as Roche Holding AG, appointed him as chief executive in 1978. A lawyer by training, he already was CEO of Zurich Insurance Co. , a job he would retain.

title: India Sets Aid Package to Counter Economic Downturn
summary: Lending to small-and-medium size enterprises worth $79 billion and other measures aim to repel the country's first economic contraction in a generation. NEW DELHI-The Indian government unveiled a large package of lending programs and other measures to stave off the country's first economic contraction in a generation and prevent an extended bout of massive unemployment.

title: Gilead's Remdesivir Tested With Other Drugs to Fight Covid-19
summary: Researchers are looking to find a more potent coronavirus-fighting cocktail. The promise and limitations of remdesivir, the first drug to prove capable of helping fight Covid-19, have kicked off efforts to see if it can work better in combination with other treatments and to create new, easier methods of administering it.

title: 'Molly Sweeney' Review: Looking at Theater Anew
summary: Brian Friel's play about a woman who undergoes surgery to regain her sight gets a stripped down, hyper-intimate online staging..

title: Britain Starts Easing Lockdown as Pressure Builds on Boris Johnson
summary: U.K. economy shrank in the first quarter but less than its peers given the government locked down later. LONDON-Britain took its first steps to ease its lockdown Wednesday as new figures showed the effects of the coronavirus pandemic on its economy, while Prime Minister Boris Johnson faced growing political pressure over his government's handling of the crisis.

title: This Property Market Needs a Safe Word
summary: In a tough real-estate market, one home listing is turning to an unusual selling point. Close to schools, new roof and a hidden passage "to your own secret playroom."

title: Will Summer Camps Open After Coronavirus Lockdowns? Your Summer 2020 Child-Care Questions Answered.
summary: For working parents who depend on camps and day care, here's what facilities are planning. The coronavirus crisis has upended summer child care plans for parents who depend on camps and day care. Now as many states move to ease lockdown measures, some camps and day cares are weighing steps to open-but others aren't sure. And parents, most importantly, want to make sure it's safe. Here's what to know.

title: U.S. Warships Support Malaysia Against China Pressure in South China Sea
summary: American officials accuse Beijing of coercing smaller countries out of developing offshore resources and say Navy presence shows U.S. commitment to region. The U.S. has sent three naval ships on patrols near oil-and-gas operations off Malaysia's coast in recent days, a show of support for the Southeast Asian nation whose offshore explorations in the South China Sea have faced pressure from China.

title: What It Takes to Make 'American Idol' in Lockdown: Confetti Cannons in the Mail
summary: Parents as crew members, producers as bandwidth police, 90 new iPhones and techniques borrowed from TikTok: Behind the scenes on the original singing-competition show. Like high-school seniors settling for virtual graduation ceremonies, finalists on ABC's "American Idol" will make do without the rock star stage rituals that would normally come with Sunday night's season finale. The show's producers are shipping a confetti cannon to each of the remaining seven contestants to fire off at home if they win.

title: What's Good for Banks Isn't Necessarily Good for Bankers
summary: Headcount was down at the largest U.S. and European investment banks despite banner first-quarter results. Investment banks had an excellent first quarter. Investment bankers weren't so lucky.

title: 'Workin' Moms' Is Back on Netflix (for Moms Who Need a Laugh Right Now)
summary: Catherine Reitman's comedy returns for its fourth season just as the world turns upside down for working moms. The coronavirus has turned many working moms into stay-at-home moms, throwing a twist in the mommy wars that nobody saw coming.

title: Companies' Next Coronavirus Challenge: Getting Cash-Strapped Shoppers to Spend
summary: Companies like Kellogg, Hershey and Nestle are tapping the lessons of the last recession as they seek ways to keep newly frugal consumers from trading down. The makers of shampoo, cereal, frozen pizza and other supermarket staples are working to woo shoppers who are cutting back on spending, as tough economic times set in.

title: Coronavirus Halted Their Wedding Plans, So These Couples Bought Homes Instead
summary: Some fiancés are switching gears from nuptials to home shopping. When they realized that their dream wedding was unlikely to happen this summer, Phil Bassis and Carly Catalana decided to do something unexpected: buy a home. They knew the Covid-19 crisis had likely shifted the market toward buyers and they hoped they might recoup some of the deposits for their wedding celebration in Manhattan.

title: Cruise Ship Photographer's Once-in-a-Lifetime Shot Anchors Just Out of Reach
summary: Resume Subscription. Just beyond the horizon, just out of his camera's reach, is the photograph of Michel Verdure's dreams.

title: Tencent Levels Up as China Hunkers Down
summary: The Chinese game giant got a huge boost from the epidemic in China last quarter, but advertising and gaming revenue growth could slow from here. Tencent , the world's largest game company, hit a high score as everyone was staying at home. Reaching the next level after the lockdown boom ends could be more challenging.

title: America Is Stuck at Home, but Food-Delivery Companies Still Struggle to Profit
summary: Coronavirus crisis creates a surge in orders but also costs, straining margins. The coronavirus pandemic handed food-delivery companies an unprecedented business opportunity: millions of Americans stuck at home, missing their favorite restaurants.

title: Hosting Coronavirus Workers Prepares Hotels for Industry's Future
summary: Hotels serving as temporary dormitories for first responders are getting a jump on post-pandemic plans, such as meeting sanitization and social-distancing guidelines. The health-care workers staying at the DoubleTree hotel in downtown Detroit had a few requests: microwaves, refrigerators and workout equipment, plus a way to get their uniforms cleaned. And maybe the hotel's signature freshly baked chocolate chip cookies?

title: China's Wuhan Revs Up Testing Amid Second-Wave Coronavirus Fears
summary: Covid-19 cases reappear in city where global outbreak began, triggering government demands for blanket testing. HONG KONG-Local officials in the Chinese city of Wuhan, the original center of the Covid-19 pandemic, are scrambling to meet government demands for a massive round of coronavirus testing following the discovery of a new cluster of infections.

title: Trump Calls for California to Let Tesla Factory Open
summary: Elon Musk says electric-vehicle maker will resume production, defying local authorities. President Trump has backed Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk's decision to resume production of cars at its California plant, siding with the electric-vehicle maker over the local government in a high-profile standoff as parts of the state consider reopening.

title: Buyers Test Coronavirus Excuse for Ditching Unwanted M&A Deals
summary: Companies argue the pandemic allows them to cancel planned transactions. Companies are betting the coronavirus pandemic is a get-out-of-deal-free card in legal fights over stalled mergers.

title: Trump Campaign Boosts Emphasis on Biden's Age, Fitness
summary: As the president trails in the polls, his latest ads depict his expected opponent appearing confused and slurring his words. WASHINGTON-President Trump's latest campaign ads target former Vice President Joe Biden's record on China, but also highlight moments when the presumptive Democratic nominee has stumbled or appeared unsteady.

title: 'There's No Escape': Finding New Ways to Help Domestic-Violence Victims Trapped in Lockdown
summary: As stay-at-home orders keep victims with abusers, authorities combat a rise in violence. One of the early texts to New York's new hotline came in: "I'm in the bathroom right now texting you. This is kind of the only chance that I have to talk to somebody."

title: As Coronavirus Cases Rise, India and Pakistan Gamble on Looser Lockdowns
summary: Resume Subscription. Despite rising numbers of Covid-19 cases, India and Pakistan are loosening their lockdowns, counting on deaths to remain low and their hospitals to be able to cope with the envisaged rise in serious cases, according to public-health specialists.

title: In Quarantine, a Look (Finally) at Unvarnished Leading Men
summary: From Kevin Hart going gray to Jake Gyllenhaal's quarantine mane, male celebrities are finally showing the world what they look like without their glam teams.. For three decades, movie star Will Smith has been regarded as a paragon of Hollywood handsomeness. Blame his barely changed features. But in quarantine, Smith's 45 million Instagram followers have noticed something new about the actor: At the age of 51, his beard has been looking a little scraggly.

title: Las Vegas Sands Ends Pursuit of Japan Casino
summary: Casino magnate Sheldon Adelson says other Asian countries will want to pursue casino-resorts. Casino magnate Sheldon Adelson's Las Vegas Sands Corp. said it has ended its pursuit of a potential $10 billion casino-resort development in Japan, regarded as one of the gambling industry's most promising countries for expansion.

title: Do-It-Yourself Haircuts: The Pros Grade the Amateurs
summary: WSJ readers shared before-and-after photos of their at-home cuts-and got strong marks, as well as pointers for next time, from people who do hair for a living. With barbershops and salons closed around the world, many individuals have been taking matters into their own hands. DIY haircuts are trending.

title: Should a 'Covid Hole in One' Count?
summary: As golf courses take measures to reduce common touchpoints, golfers aren't sure what counts as an ace. Tony Burgess secured the first tee time on the first day that Boulder Creek Golf Club in Boulder Creek, Calif., reopened, and something magical happened. Or maybe it was the big lie of coronavirus golf.

title: New York City's Virus Lockdown Means New Challenges for Rats and Local Wildlife
summary: Animals have more space to roam but food has become more scarce and some bird habitats may face disruption. The coronavirus lockdown has left some of New York City's most resourceful residents with a gnawing question: Where has all the food gone?

title: Plant-Based Food Makers' Mouths Water Amid Meat Shortages
summary: Beef producers racing to meet consumer demand say any shortfalls are temporary, as sellers of meat alternatives look to seize opportunity. Plant-based food makers are racing to fill in for missing cuts in supermarket meat cases, after the coronavirus disrupted operations at meatpacking plants.

title: How Real-Estate Agents Close Deals During Coronavirus
summary: Two Manhattan-based brokers describe what it's been like closing sales during New York's Covid-19 shutdown. Dorothy Schrager

title: From Odessa to Burgundy: The Tale of a Ukrainian Hunt for Justice
summary: A businessman's death certificate ended his fraud trial-and launched a detour on Ukraine's rocky road to legal credibility. LA ROCHEPOT, France-It was 2014, and prosecutors were closing in on an elusive Ukrainian businessman wanted on fraud charges, when the case took an unexpected turn. His death certificate and a cremation urn appeared on the doorstep of his relatives' Odessa apartment.

title: House Races in California and Nebraska Test Mail-in Voting
summary: GOP candidate Garcia leads in California special election for House seat, while liberal candidate Eastman wins Nebraska Democratic primary during coronavirus pandemic. A pair of congressional races held on Tuesday-largely through mail-in voting-is offering an early look at how the coronavirus pandemic is reshaping elections ahead of November's presidential contest.

title: After 23 Days, Coronavirus Creeps Back in Hong Kong as Local Transmissions Are Reported
summary: 'If anyone can get to the bottom of it, Hong Kong can,' doctor says. HONG KONG-After 23 days without a locally transmitted coronavirus case and with much of the city returning to normal life, health officials here are investigating how a 66-year-old woman and her granddaughter tested positive.

title: Bank Resurrected During Crisis Takes Fresh Hits
summary: ABN Amro says massive losses in oil and derivatives trading pushed it into a loss in the most recent quarter. European banks largely averted big-ticket client losses in the first quarter despite massive oil-price swings and the regional outbreak of the coronavirus. That wasn't the case for ABN Amro Bank NV, a Dutch lender nationalized during the 2008 financial crisis that is once again licking its wounds.

title: Sony Sees Sharp Drop in Operating Profit Even Under Favorable Scenario
summary: Fall of more than 30% forecast despite strong sales of image sensors for 5G smartphones. Sony Corp. said it expected operating income to fall by at least 30% in the current fiscal year assuming that business operations return to normal by the end of 2020, citing slower sales of electronics and life insurance.

title: What Doesn't Kill Fast Food Makes It Stronger
summary: Restaurant chains like McDonald's and Chipotle aren't only surviving in the U.S., but also thriving despite deep economic slump. Not even the full force of a global pandemic can keep U.S. fast-food sales down for long.

title: Summer Camp Canceled? IRS Gives Relief for Dependent-Care Accounts
summary: Employees will likely be able to make midyear changes to plans, according to new guidance. Americans who use tax-favored workplace plans to pay for children's day-care or summer-camp expenses will likely be able to make midyear changes to them, according to new guidance from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: New York Transit Workers Hard Hit by Virus Return to Work Fearing Exposure
summary: Thousands of New York's subway, bus and rail employees are returning from quarantine or sick leave after 116 of their colleagues have died. Arnita Simon got back behind the wheel of the B16 bus in Brooklyn at the end of April after three weeks out sick with Covid-19.

title: The Stock Market Is Crazy Expensive-And That's OK
summary: Our columnist says Wall Street's favorite valuation metric, the price-to-earnings ratio, has been broken by the coronavirus disruption. Stocks are at their most expensive since the dot-com crash two decades ago, according to Wall Street's standard valuation metric. But the forward price-to-earnings ratio is broken, and alternatives show the market is cheaper, even if it's still no bargain.

title: For Japan Inc., Faxing Fizzles and Coronavirus Compels Conference Calls
summary: 'There still exist many illogical business customs in Japan,' says one CEO, but the pandemic has brought big changes. TOKYO-When Panasonic Corp. releases its latest results on Monday, it will try something unknown in its century of history. It won't hand out stapled papers with the numbers, and it won't ask analysts and reporters to go in person to Tokyo or Osaka to hear executives speak.

title: Coronavirus Dried Up This Production Company's Business. Then It Created Remote Shooting Kits.
summary: New York-based Hayden5 says revenue has picked back up since it began offering drop-offs of sterilized video production kits. To shoot its music-video cover of Lil Nas X's hit "Panini" in April, the children's entertainment brand Kidz Bop Entertainment LLC needed to direct and choreograph young performers in four cities-while navigating the stay-at-home orders of the pandemic.

title: Coronavirus Has Been a Boon for China's Railways
summary: With the pandemic choking sea and air freight, companies turn to the trains revived as part of Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative. SHANGHAI-The coronavirus pandemic is boosting a core element of China's Belt and Road Initiative, as rising prices and disruptions in sea and air shipping force companies to turn to trains.

title: Companies Start Reaping Billions in Tax Breaks to Help Ride Out Slump
summary: Oil refiners, restaurant operators count on cushion from tax deferrals and breaks in March coronavirus relief package. WASHINGTON-New tax breaks expected to total about $650 billion are starting to flow to U.S. businesses, giving them quick cash and longer-term help to ride out the coronavirus-induced economic downturn.

title: Consumers Seeking Debt Relief Face Jammed Phone Lines, Overwhelmed Lenders
summary: Customer-service departments are stretched thin as millions of borrowers request break on payments. Teri Carter Beahm was out of work and nearly out of money when she called Citigroup Inc. on March 30, two days before a $64 credit-card payment was due.

title: Old Vaccine Gets New Look in Tests for Coronavirus Protection
summary: Researchers see promise in using BCG, a 100-year-old tuberculosis shot, until a vaccination for the new virus is developed. Trials have begun on what researchers say could be a stopgap vaccination against the new coronavirus, testing a century-old tuberculosis vaccine on thousands of people including police in India, health-care workers in Texas and elderly people in the Netherlands.

title: India Tests the Limits of Public Finance in Emerging Markets
summary: Who exactly is going to fund the country's stimulus?. The Indian government promised a blockbuster economic stimulus Tuesday that lifted the country's stocks. But the country's economic circumstances looked bleak even before the pandemic began, and it is unclear who the buyers for all this debt will be. The central bank may eventually need to step into the breach.

title: Fauci, Other Top Health Officials Emphasize Testing Before Easing Lockdowns
summary: At Senate hearing, experts warn of potential for coronavirus surge as states move to reopen. Top Trump administration health officials emphasized the need for caution and widespread testing while easing coronavirus lockdowns, warning in a Senate hearing that serious risks would continue into the fall as schools looked to reopen.

title: Covid-19 Will Change Airlines, Not Airline Economics
summary: Carriers and airports will take a while to adjust to weak demand and new health measures, but this isn't the end of cheap travel. Could Covid-19 take the airline industry back to the 1990s, when roomier planes flew fewer people on fewer routes at higher prices? Nostalgia should be kept in check.

title: Trump Calls for California to Let Tesla Factory Open
summary: Elon Musk says electric-vehicle maker will resume production, defying local authorities. President Trump has backed Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk's decision to resume production of cars at its California plant, siding with the electric-vehicle maker over the local government in a high-profile standoff as parts of the state consider reopening.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Judge Puts Up Potential Roadblock to Dropping Charge Against Flynn
summary: Unusual order invites other individuals and organizations to give views on dismissing case. A federal judge on Tuesday indicated he would not immediately rubber-stamp the Justice Department's move to drop the criminal case against former national security adviser Michael Flynn, saying he would instead allow other individuals and organizations to weigh in on the extraordinary request.

title: Canada Agency to Suspend Advance Look at Jobs Data
summary: Statistics Canada ends longstanding practice for ministers after a leak last week. OTTAWA-Canada's data-gathering agency has suspended its practice of providing select senior government officials a sneak peek of its market-moving employment report after the April figures were leaked and published on Friday before their scheduled release.

title: FEMA Cancels $55.5 Million Mask Contract
summary: Vendor had no history in the mask business and a parent company in bankruptcy. The federal government said it canceled a $55.5 million contract for respiratory masks, signed last month with a small Virginia firm with no history in the mask business and a parent company in bankruptcy.

title: Supreme Court Hears Trump Lawyers' Appeal to Stop Handover of Tax Documents
summary: Justices ask why president should be able to stop House accessing his records when Nixon and Clinton were required to comply. WASHINGTON-President Trump's lawyers asked the Supreme Court on Tuesday to quash congressional and criminal subpoenas seeking financial records from his bankers and accountants, as long-simmering controversies over Mr. Trump's private business affairs came into focus ahead of the full blaze of the presidential campaign.

title: As Countries Ease Coronavirus Lockdowns, New Cases Emerge
summary: In U.S., some governors seek federal help to help pay for public health, public-safety services, schools. Some governors sought more help from Washington as they moved to restart their economies, while new clusters of coronavirus infections cropped up in parts of the Middle East and Asia after authorities loosened lockdowns.

title: Lawyer Accuses Walmart of Wrongful Termination Following Bribery Probe
summary: Former ethics officer says he was falsely accused of child abuse and questionable behavior. Walmart says he was fired for cause.. A former in-house lawyer for Walmart Inc. has accused the retail giant of drumming up false claims of child abuse and inappropriate workplace conduct to undermine his work investigating bribery allegations in Mexico.

title: Telegram Ends Cryptocurrency Project After Regulatory Roadblocks
summary: The Dubai-based company raised $1.7 billion from investors for its Telegram Open Network, or TON, blockchain project. Telegram Group Inc. is giving up on its Telegram Open Network cryptocurrency project following a battle with U.S. regulators, Pavel Durov, founder and chief executive of the messaging company, wrote in a blog post.
